## OBSTRUCTION

Characters and objects block movement into the spaces they occupy. This is called obstruction .

Obstructions prevent movement if they are the same SIZE as the moving character or larger.

If an obstruction is an allied character or an enemy character smaller than you, they do not count as an obstruction and you can move through their spaces; however, you can't end a movement sharing spaces with another character.

If an obstruction is an object that is smaller than you, you can climb on it at no additional movement cost.

## ENGAGEMENT

Characters gain the ENGAGED status when they are adjacent to one or more enemies. This is called ENGAGEMENT .

When you become ENGAGED with an enemy of your SIZE or larger, your movement ends and you lose any unused movement. Once ENGAGED , you can begin new movements normally. Moving adjacent to a character with who you are already ENGAGED doesn't stop your movement, since you are still ENGAGED . The movement-ending effect only occurs when ENGAGED is applied.

While ENGAGED , you receive +1 to all ranged attacks.

## DIFFICULT TERRAIN

Difficult terrain is anything that slows movement, like mud, water, or thick grass. Difficult terrain has +1 movement cost.

For example, if Dhalia has SPEED 5 , she can normally move 5 spaces. If she moves into a space of difficult terrain, it would cost 2 spaces worth of movement instead 1. She would only have 3 spaces of movement left, even though she only moved one space.

## DANGEROUS TERRAIN

Dangerous terrain is any type of terrain that can cause damage, like lava or thorns.

1/round , when you enter dangerous terrain or end your turn in it, you must make an ability check of the GM's choice. Failure: Y ou take 5 damage of any type or Stress based on the type of terrain.

For example, if the ground is covered in freezing water, the GM might decide that it triggers a BULK check and deals Lunar damage.

## ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS

Environmental factors are effects that alter combat scenes, individual spaces, or even objects. Some apply to the entire combat scene, while others affect characters in smaller areas, such as in the case of a room with poor visibility.

This section lists some of the more common environmental factors. A full list of environmental factors can be found in Chapter 10: Game Master's Guide (Environmental Factors and Terrain Features, p. 223).

## LOCKS

Doors, gates, and treasure chests can all be locked, preventing them from being opened. A locked entrance - a bolted door, for instance - can't be moved through. The contents of chests and other objects that are locked can't be accessed.

To unlock something, you can make an AGILITY check as part of the action to interact with it. On a success, the lock is disabled and the object is opened.

## LOW VISIBILITY

Low visibility can represent darkness, fog, and other effects that make it hard to see. It affects how far characters can see, and makes it harder to find HIDDEN characters. Low visibility has the following effects:

- Ø Characters are INVISIBLE while HIDDEN .
- Ø SCOPE and the Range of all weapons are reduced by half. Reach and AOEs are not affected.

## UNDERWATER/ZERO-GRAVITY

Combat scenes that take place completely underwater or in zero-gravity treat all characters as FLYING . However, unless they have flight or an Aquatic Adaptation (granted by certain abilities), they can't RUSH or shift .

## ADAPTATIONS

Some abilities grant an adaptation to specific types of environments, like Aquatic Adaptation . Characters with an adaptation to an environment are immune to any of its negative effects. If it's not clear whether an effect is negative or not, the character with the adaptation can decide. Adaptations only affect the character with an adaptation. The Low Visibility environmental factor, for example, states that all characters are INVISIBLE while HIDDEN . A character with an adaptation to that environment could decide that they don't want to be INVISIBLE while HIDDEN , because that affects them directly, but they couldn't ignore the INVISIBLE status on other HIDDEN characters, because that's an effect on other characters.

## TERRAIN FEATURES

Terrain features modify spaces and terrain on the battlefield. While they generally affect single spaces, multiple terrain features can be placed next to each other to create a continuous feature. For example, you can have a single space of lava as dangerous terrain, but you could also connect multiple lava spaces to create a lava flow, all of which count as the same piece of dangerous terrain. Cover (p. 50), difficult terrain (p. 56), and dangerous terrain (p. 56) all count as terrain features. This section lists some of the most common terrain features. A full list of terrain features can be found in Chapter 10: Game Master's Guide (Environmental Factors and Terrain Features, p. 251).

## EMPTY SPACE/FREE SPACE

A free space is a space that doesn't contain any characters or objects. Empty spaces, on the other hand, are more specific than free spaces. Empty spaces are those that don't contain any characters, objects, terrain, or terrain features.

Some abilities affect free spaces, while others will affect empty spaces only.

## HIGH GROUND

High ground provides benefits that represent being at a higher elevation than other characters, similar to those received when FLYING . Characters standing on high ground gain the following benefits:

- Ø Non-thrown melee attacks against them from nonFLYING characters that aren't on high ground receive +2 .
- Ø They  neither  become ENGAGED by  nor  cause ENGAGEMENT to nonFLYING characters that aren't on high ground.
- Ø Their  attacks  gain +1 against  nonFLYING characters that aren't on high ground.

Accessing high ground sometimes requires special movement, like flying or climbing.

## IMPASSABLE TERRAIN

Impassable terrain is any terrain, like a wall or a cliff, that cannot normally be traversed except by characters who possess a type of movement that allows them to do so, like flying or climbing. Some impassable terrain cannot be entered at all (e.g., a pillar that reaches up to the ceiling or the walls of an underground dungeon).

## TRAPS

Traps are interactable objects with the Trap tag (p. 65). While many Traps are PC or NPC abilities, you can use these Traps to represent Traps already on the battlefield.

## DAMAGE TRAP

The triggering character takes 6/8/10 damage of any type, chosen when the Trap is set.

## AREA DAMAGE TRAP

When triggered, all characters in a BURST 1 AOE must make a save of the GM's choice. Failure: The target takes 6/8/10 damage of any type, chosen when the Trap is set. Success: They take 3/4/5 damage instead.

## CONDITION TRAP

The triggering character gains a condition based on the type of Trap . IMMOBILIZED , SLOWED , and BLINDED are common.

## AREA CONDITION TRAP

When triggered, all characters in a BURST 1 AOE must make a save of the GM's choice. Failure: They gain a condition, chosen when the Trap is set.

## TREASURE CHESTS

Treasure chests are objects that don't cause obstruction and that contain bonus effects for the players, chosen from the table below. Players always know the contents of chests. The GM can decide if the bonuses apply to the character that opened the chest or everyone on their team. Some bonuses provide immediate effects, while others provide delayed effects or permanent resources.

Chests can be accessed with a minor action while in their space, but might be locked (see the locked environmental feature).

## EXAMPLE CHEST REWARDS

- 1 A reroll on the next loot crate's first slot. Subsequent instances of this bonus increase the slot that can be rerolled. For example, getting this reward twice means that you can reroll either the first or second slot.
- 2 +X GOLD
- 3 +X RECOVERIES

4

Repair a destroyed weapon/support item/technique

- 5 A specific piece of loot
- 6 Regain X uses of a Consumable ability

7

Increase current and total MP by X for the rest of the scene

8

Clear all Stress

## DAMAGE AND STRESS

Characters inflict harm on their enemies to wear them down and eventually defeat them. The most common sources of damage are attacks, but other abilities and effects can also inflict damage.

When you take damage, you subtract the damage taken from your current HP . For example, if you would take 5 PHYSICAL , your HP would be reduced by 5. ARMOR (p. 15) and other effects can change the amount of damage you take. When your HP reaches 0, you take a Wound (p. 60).

Stress is another type of harm separate from damage. Stress is accumulated until it exceeds your STRESS CAP , at which point you take an Overstress (p. 60).

There are five standard types of damage Physical , Force , Astral , Lunar , and Discord :

<!-- image -->

Physical: Damage from slashing, bludgeoning, and piercing weapons, and other physical sources.

<!-- image -->

<!-- image -->

<!-- image -->

<!-- image -->

Force: Damage caused by explosions and pure arcane energies.

Astral: Damage caused by heat, light, and other energy sources associated with the radiance of stars. Fire, light, and electricity are commonly associated with the Astral.

Lunar: Damage caused by cold, darkness, and other energy sources associated with the stillness of the moon. Ice, dark, and acid are commonly associated with the Lunar.

Discord: Damage that disrupts aetheric fields and puts its victims into a state of aetheric discord, like poison, burns, and blood loss, sapping the sufferer's lifeforce over time.

Physical, Force, Astral, and Lunar damage all function the same way, but certain abilities can make characters VULNERABLE , resistant , or immune to certain damage types (see facing page).

Discord has additional rules associated with it, as it has a damage over time component (see below).

## ORDER OF DAMAGE

To determine the final amount of damage dealt by any given action or effect, follow these steps in order:

- 1 Roll damage and bonus damage.
- 2 Halve bonus damage if there is more than one target.
- 3 Apply the effects of WEAKENED or VULNERABLE , where relevant.
- 4 Subtract damage equal to the target's ARMOR .
- 5 If RESISTANCE applies, halve any relevant remaining damage.
- 6 Deal the remaining damage (rounded up) to the target.

## DISCORD

Discord is a unique type of damage that deals discord damage to its victim's HP over time. It stacks with other Discord (see below) and is always Piercing .

Discord applies damage every turn. Whenever you take Discord, you immediately take Piercing Discord damage equal to the amount of Discord gained. You then make a note of the amount of Discord gained, adding it to any Discord you already have.

Make a MAGIC check at the end of each of your turns while you have Discord. Success: You clear all Discord. Failure: You take Discord damage equal to your current Discord.

Discord levels stacks. For example, if you have 2 Discord and gain another 2 Discord, you would have a total of 4 Discord.

RESISTANCE and VULNERABLE apply only to the upfront Discord you take (and, therefore, the amount of ongoing Discord you gain), not to the discord damage you take if you fail the MAGIC check to clear it.

## STRESS

<!-- image -->

Stress is a special type of harm that doesn't count  as  damage,  and  doesn't  affect  the recipient's HP .

Instead of being subtracted from your HP , Stress is accumulated. When your Stress exceeds your BREAKING point, you gain the BREAKING status (p. 63), and when it exceeds your STRESS CAP , you take an Overstress (p. 60).

Some characters (like Summons ) don't have a STRESS CAP . If these characters would take Stress , they instead take the same amount of Force .

Because Stress isn't damage, it ignores ARMOR and effects that modify damage don't modify Stress unless otherwise indicated. Taking Stress doesn't count as taking damage.

## BONUS DAMAGE

Bonus damage is additional damage added onto an existing source of damage. Bonus damage is granted by abilities and effects.

Bonus damage is only ever added to successful attacks or abilities that deal damage . It can only be Physical, Astral, Lunar, or Force damage (not Discord or Stress). Its type is the same as that of the underlying, basic damage, unless otherwise indicated. If an attack or ability normally deals multiple types of damage (e.g., Physical and Lunar), the character dealing the damage picks one for the bonus damage.

Effects with more than one target, like AOE attacks, only deal half their bonus damage to each target. Importantly, this applies only if there is more than one target, not if there could be multiple targets. If you attack with a BLAST 1 explosion but there is only one target in the area, they take the full bonus damage. If there are two targets, the bonus damage would be halved.

Linked attacks don't deal bonus damage - only the first attack in the linked pair does.

## VULNERABLE AND WEAKENED

The VULNERABLE and WEAKENED conditions affect how much damage characters take and deal. VULNERABLE characters take double damage, and WEAKENED characters deal half damage.

Modifications to damage from VULNERABLE and WEAKENED happen before ARMOR and resistances . The full rules of these conditions can be found later in this chapter (p. 62).

Example: Dhalia is currently WEAKENED and uses a spell attack that deals 4 ASTRAL . Her damage is reduced to 2 ASTRAL because of her WEAKENED condition. If her target has 1 ARMOR , they would take a total of 1 ASTRAL from Dhalia's attack.

Dmitri, on the other hand, is currently VULNERABLE to Lunar damage . He triggers a Trap that explodes and deals 4 LUNAR . Because he is VULNERABLE to that damage type, he instead takes 8 LUNAR . Dmitri then subtracts his 2 ARMOR , taking a total of 6 LUNAR .

## ARMOR, RESISTANCE, AND IMMUNITY

Armor reduces a set amount of damage, resistance halves damage, and immunity reduces damage to 0. Resistance and immunity often apply to specific types of damage.

Armor reduces incoming Physical, Astral, Lunar, and Force equal to its value. ARMOR does not reduce Stress or Discord . For example, 2 ARMOR would reduce Physical damage taken from an attack by 2.

ARMOR applies to each separate source of damage. For example, if you are hit by two attacks in a turn, ARMOR would apply to each attack.

Resistance halves any incoming damage of an indicated type, or even Stress. For example, if you would take 10 ASTRAL and have resistance to Astral , you only take 5 ASTRAL .

Immunity negates all incoming damage or Stress from whatever it is you have immunity against. For example, if you would take 4 STRESS and have Immunity to Stress , you take no Stress at all.

## OBJECT AND TERRAIN DAMAGE

Objects and pieces of terrain can take damage. By default, they have 10 HP per SIZE , 5 DODGE , and are immune to Aetheric attacks and Stress.

The GM may allow objects and terrain to be broken in smaller segments. For example, you might punch a hole through a wall instead of destroying the entire wall at once.

In some cases, the GM may allow for objects or terrain to be broken with successful a BULK check. This might be the case if you try to ram down a wooden door.

In general, the ground does not take damage. This can be ignored in certain situations, like if you want to destroy the floor in a house to fall into the basement. But in most cases, no one needs to track how much damage the ground is taking.

## WOUNDS AND OVERSTRESS

In combat, characters can receive Wounds or become Overstressed . As they accumulate Wounds and Overstresses, their combat performance weakens until they are no longer able to fight.

## Wounds

When a character reaches 0 HP , they take a Wound and make a wound roll .

When you reach 0 HP , you take a Wound and reset your HP , carrying over any excess damage. You then make a wound roll by rolling 1d6 and consulting the Wound Table to see what additional penalties you suffer.

Beacons have a WOUND CAP of 4, while NPCs usually have different WOUND CAPS (p. 260). When you have Wounds equal to your WOUND CAP , you are defeated .

## Overstressed

When a PC takes Stress in excess of their STRESS CAP , they take an Overstress . NPCs follow different rules when they exceed their STRESS CAP (p. 260).

When you take Stress , it accumulates until it exceeds your STRESS CAP . If you go over your STRESS CAP , you take an Overstress and reset your Stress, carrying over any excess Stress. If this causes you to exceed your STRESS CAP a second time, you take another Overstress. When you receive an Overstress, you also make an overstress roll by rolling 1d6 and consulting the Overstress Table to see what additional penalties you suffer.

Beacons have an OVERSTRESS CAP of 4, while NPCs usually have different OVERSTRESS CAPS (p. 260). When you have Overstresses equal to your OVERSTRESS CAP , you are defeated .

| | | | WOUND TABLE (roll 1d6 depending on current wounds remaining) |
|-|-|-|--------------------------------------------------------------|
|3|2|1|Description |
|5-6|6|-|DAZED: You are DAZED until the end of your next turn.|
|3-4|4-5|5-6| Broken Weapon: Destroy one of your weapons. Limited and Consumable equipment can only be selected if they have charges remaining. If you can’t destroy a weapon, this becomes the Broken Support Item result. If you can’t destroy a support item either, this becomes the Staggered result.|
|1-2|2-3|3-4|Broken Support Item: Destroy one of your support items. Limited and Consumable equipment can only be selected if they have charges remaining. If you can’t destroy a support item, this becomes the Broken Weapon result. If you can’t destroy a weapon either, this becomes the Staggered result.|
|-|1|1-2| Staggered: You are Slowed and Stunned until the end of your next turn.|    


## Defeat

Although defeat doesn't always mean death, defeated characters can no longer contribute to a scene.

When a character is defeated, all effects on them and that originated from them are removed, like Summons or the effects of the Hexblade's HEX . Damage, conditions, statuses, and created objects and terrain remain, including Traps .

When your beacon is defeated, you can narrate how they're defeated, whether it involves being knocked out or running away. They are then removed from play and unable to directly contribute to the scene.

NPCs are typically killed or knocked unconscious when defeated, as chosen by whoever defeated them. The GM can choose a different outcome, but they can't kill an NPC that a player wanted to keep alive unless the player gives their permission.

## RESTING

Resting allows PCs to heal, recover resources, and repair equipment.

There are two types of rests: Short Rests and Long Rests . Short Rests are quick breaks that allow beacons to patch themselves up after a fight, while Long Rests are longer and more restorative. Individual beacons can choose to skip a Short Rest, receiving none of the benefits, but they can't skip a Long Rest.

Abilities that reference a rest but don't specify what kind of rest apply to both Short and Long Rests. For example, the Shadebinder's COMPANION SHADE ability creates a friendly summoned shade on the battlefield. The shade regains all its HP during any rest, which means it regains all its HP when you take either a Short Rest or a Long Rest.

The GM determines when the beacons are able to take rests. You can't declare you are resting unless the GM allows it.

## Short Rests

During Short Rests, the beacons can spend RECOVERIES to replenish their resources.

Short Rests are taken during quests, and only require that the beacons take a few moments to catch their breath. Short Rests are often available between combat scenes. During a Short Rest, you may do the following:

- Ø Clear all Stress.
- Ø Regain all MP .
- Ø Reload all Reloading abilities.
- Ø Clear all conditions, statuses, and effects (except for BLOODIED and BREAKING , if still applicable).

You can also spend RECOVERIES for the following:

- 1 RECOVERY

Regain all HP .

- 1 RECOVERY

Repair a destroyed technique or piece of equipment.

- 1 RECOVERY

Restore maximum MP to its normal value.

- 2 RECOVERIES

Clear 1 Wound or Overstress .

- 2 RECOVERIES

Change your current job. Your HP , Stress , MP , and RECOVERIES remain at their current values unless the new job's maximum is lower, in which case they are reduced to the new maximum. If the new job doesn't have sufficient slots for your current weapons, support items, or techniques, you must unequip items and techniques until they fit.

- 4 RECOVERIES

Return a defeated character to play. The required RECOVERIES can be split between any characters participating in the Short Rest, including the defeated character. The defeated character returns to play with 3 Wounds , 3 Overstresses , full HP and MP , and no Stress . You can only bring a defeated character back into play if the player is willing.

## Long Rest

During Long Rests, the beacons fully heal, recover their resources, and repair damaged equipment and techniques.

A Long Rest is an extended period of rest and recovery that typically takes place between quests. A Long Rest must be long enough for the beacons to sleep, eat, and repair their equipment.

The beacons always benefit from a Long Rest between quests. There may be time for a Long Rest during a particularly lengthy quest, but that is for the GM to decide.

During a Long Rest, defeated beacons are brought back into play if their player wishes. Additionally, each PC may do the following:

- Ø Reset all attributes to their normal values (e.g., full HP and MP , no Stress/conditions/Wounds, etc).
- Ø Change their job, ancestry trait, equipment, and other options.
- Ø Repair all equipment and techniques.

## CONDITIONS AND STATUSES

Conditions and statuses are continuous effects that can be applied to characters. Conditions represent short-term, specific consequences that usually have finite durations and are applied by abilities, while statuses are ongoing states that are usually applied when certain conditions are met.

## CONDITIONS

Conditions are always negative. Most effects that give conditions indicate when the conditions end (e.g., 'until the end of the target's next turn'). They can also be cleared with REFRESH .

## BLINDED

BLINDED characters can only target and draw line of sight to adjacent spaces.

## DAZED

DAZED characters receive +1 on all attacks, checks, and saves.

## DISARMED

DISARMED characters can't make weapon attacks except for improvised weapon attacks.

## IMMOBILIZED

IMMOBILIZED characters can't voluntarily move, but can still be subjected to forced and involuntary movement.

## MARKED

When attacking a MARKED character, the attacker can choose to consume the MARK. Doing this clears MARKED and grants +1 on that attack roll. A character can only have one MARK at a time.

## SILENCED

SILENCED characters can't use or RELEASE spells.

## SLOWED

SLOWED characters can only move with their standard movement; they can't RUSH or use any other forms of voluntary movement.

SLOWED PCs can only take their turns in PHASE DELAY . SLOWED NPCs have their next Initiative become 8 (this lasts until they've taken that turn and the condition ends). During rounds in which they are SLOWED , Bosses must take at least one of their turns during PHASE DELAY , even if they clear the condition before doing so.

<!-- image -->

## STUNNED

STUNNED characters can perform either a standard action or a minor action on their turns, not both. Additionally, they can't FULL ATTACK or perform reactions , and their DODGE and A-DEF both count as 5.

## SUNDERED

SUNDERED characters don't benefit from ARMOR or resistance .

## VULNERABLE

VULNERABLE characters take double damage from Physical, Astral, Lunar, and Force sources. Stress and Discord are not affected.

## WEAKENED

WEAKENED characters deal half damage when dealing Physical, Force, Astral, and Lunar. Stress and Discord are not affected. Their Summons and Traps are also unaffected.

## STATUSES

Statuses describe characters' current states, and can be positive or negative. Unlike conditions, they can't be removed unless specific actions are taken or their requirements no longer apply.

## BLOODIED

Characters are BLOODIED when they have half of their HP maximum or less (their BLOODIED level).

## BREAKING

Characters are BREAKING when they have Stress equal to or exceeding half their STRESS CAP (their BREAKING point).

## ENGAGED

When a character becomes adjacent to an enemy, they both gain the ENGAGED status as long as they are adjacent to one another. ENGAGED characters make ranged attacks at +1 . If a character becomes ENGAGED by another character of the same SIZE or larger, their movement ends and they lose any unused movement. C haracters cease to be ENGAGED when they are no longer adjacent to an enemy.

## FLYING

Characters with flight can either take off, gaining the FLYING status, or land on the ground, clearing the status, as a free action once per turn. They can also choose to start combat scenes FLYING .

While a character is FLYING , the following effects apply :

- Ø Non-thrown  melee  attacks  from  nonFLYING characters gain +2 against them.
- Ø They can move normally over and are immune to the effects of terrain, obstructions, and terrain features, but cannot benefit from or interact with them either. When flying over objects, they are considered to have their SIZE increased by the SIZE of whatever they are flying over for the purposes of determining line of sight and cover, as if they were climbing .
- Ø They cannot benefit from cover from terrain or objects.
- Ø When attacking nonFLYING characters, they treat their target's cover from terrain and objects as one step lower (hard cover becomes soft cover, soft cover becomes no cover).
- Ø They  ignore ENGAGEMENT and  don't  cause ENGAGEMENT .
- Ø They don't trigger Traps but can still be affected by them.
- Ø They cease to be FLYING if they become PRONE .

## GRAPPLED

GRAPPLED always involves at least two characters, both of whom receive the status. While GRAPPLED , the following effects apply:

- Ø Both characters are ENGAGED.
- Ø Neither character can take reactions .
- Ø The larger character can move normally.
- Ø The smaller character is IMMOBILIZED , but is dragged along by the larger character when they move, mirroring their movements and inheriting any special forms of movement like flight .
- Ø If the initiator is the same SIZE as the target, they count as the larger one during the turn in which they initiate the GRAPPLE .
- Ø Characters of the same SIZE can make a contested BULK check as a free action to see if they count as the larger one until this contest is repeated.

GRAPPLED ends when one of the following occurs:

- Ø The characters are no longer adjacent to each other.
- Ø The initiator ends it as a free action .
- Ø The GRAPPLE target succeeds on a contested BULK check as a minor action .

## HIDDEN

While a character is HIDDEN , enemies can only target them with AOEs or while adjacent to them. They are still visible on the combat map to players and the GM. The following things end HIDDEN :

- Ø The HIDDEN character uses a hostile effect (e.g., attacking or forcing a save) or uses INTERPOSE .
- Ø The HIDDEN character ends any turn within an enemy's line of sight unless they are either INVISIBLE or benefiting from cover against that enemy.
- Ø An enemy performs a successful SEARCH against them.

## INVISIBLE

When making an attack against an INVISIBLE character, before any attack rolls are made, roll a d6. On a 1-3, the attack misses. INVISIBLE characters are still visible on the map to players and the GM. INVISIBLE lasts until the end of the scene unless stated otherwise.

## PRONE

Attacks against PRONE targets gain +1 and PRONE characters always count as moving through difficult terrain . Unless they are IMMOBILIZED , PRONE characters can stand instead of making their standard movement, which ends this status. Standing doesn't count as a form of movement.

## TAGS

Abilities often have tags associated with them, such as Aura 2 , Piercing , or Polymorph . When an ability has a tag, the effects of that tag apply to the effects of that ability. Some abilities don't have tags, but do have effects that have a tag, or that create objects or characters with the tag, as indicated in their description.

If an ability has a tag with a value of 'X' , like Mana X, that means the amount can vary, but must be at least 1. Below is a list of tags and their effects.

Accurate: Attacks with this tag gain +1 .

Aetheric: Attacks with this tag are made against A-DEF instead of DODGE .

Arcing: Abilities with this tag can be aimed over obstacles. They ignore line of sight as long as there is a vertical path to the target, although cover still applies.

Armor: Abilities with this tag represent suits of armor or similar defenses, many of which provide a bonus to ARMOR . A character can only have one ability with this tag equipped at a time.

Aura X: When activated, abilities with this tag affect indicated characters within X spaces of the user. A character can only have one Aura activated at a time and can change Auras 1/turn.

Auto-Hit: Attacks with this tag automatically hit without making an attack roll.

Blast X: Abilities with this tag have an AOE. It affects all targets within a radius of X spaces from the center space, including the center space . Cover and line of sight are calculated from the center space. Users can be affected by their own Blast .

Burst X: Affects all targets within a radius of X spaces from the edge of the spaces occupied by the target, including the target's spaces but excluding the target itself . Cover and line of sight are calculated from the edge of the spaces occupied by the target. If a Burst forms a zone , the zone moves with the target.

Close Blast X: Abilities with this tag have an AOE. It operates like a Blast , but:

-  at least 1 space must be adjacent to the user
-  the user can't be in the area
-  cover and line of sight are calculated from the user.

Consumable X: Abilities with this tag can only be used X times per quest. Consumable abilities represent potions, elixirs, and other items that can be replenished.

Enchantment: Abilities with this tag modify other abilities. Enchantments can typically only be applied to specific types of abilities and can only be applied to one ability at a time. Additionally, each ability can only have one Enchantment at a time. Enchantments can only be applied to a new ability while preparing for a quest or during a Long Rest . If an Enchantment is destroyed, the ability it is enchanting is not destroyed and vice versa. Traits and talents can't be enchanted.

Focus X: Abilities with this tag cost X Focus to use.

Homing: Abilities with this tag ignore line of sight and the effects of cover. As long as the target is within Range and it is possible to reach them (i.e., they aren't in a box), they can be targeted.

Inaccurate: Attacks with this tag receive +1 .

Indirect: Attacks with this tag ignore any from cover.

Innate: Abilities with this tag can't be destroyed or enchanted. They can't be chosen for destruction as the result of a wound roll.

Limited X: Abilities with this tag can only be used X times per quest. Limited abilities provide powerful effects that can't be replenished during a quest once used.

Line X: Abilities with this tag have an AOE. It affects all targets in a straight line with a length of X spaces and a width of 1 space, drawn directly away from you in any direction.

Mana X: Abilities with this tag cost X MP to use.

Piercing: Damage with this tag ignores ARMOR .

Polymorph: Abilities with this tag modify the target's form. A character can only be under the effect of one ability with this tag at a time, and any subsequent polymorph effects are automatically cancelled while they are under the effects of a polymorph.

Pull X: Abilities with this tag inflict a type of forced movement. On a hit, the target is moved X spaces directly toward the origin.

Push X: Abilities with this tag inflict a type of forced movement. On a hit, the target is moved X spaces directly away from the origin.

Range X: Abilities with this tag can be used on targets within X spaces.

Reach X: Abilities with this tag can be used on targets within X spaces. This tag also determines the range of the OPPORTUNITY ATTACK reaction.

Reliable X: Abilities with this tag always deal at least X damage, even if they would miss or deal less than X damage. Reliable damage inherits the ability's damage type and tags; however, Reliable damage does not count as a hit and doesn't trigger any effects that require a hit.

Reloading: Abilities with this tag must be reloaded after each use before they can be used again. This can be done using REFRESH and other abilities.

Slide X: Abilities with this tag inflict a type of forced movement. On a hit, the target is moved X spaces in any direction.

Slow: Abilities with this tag can only be activated as part of FULL ATTACK .

Stressful X: Abilities with this tag inflict X Stress on the user.

Summon: Abilities with this tag create one or more temporary characters under the control of another character, each of which has the Summon tag.

By default, each character can only have one Summon per ability with this tag in play at a time. If a Summon is defeated or dismissed, a new one can be made using that same ability. Summons can't create Summons.

Thrown X: Abilities with this tag can be used to make a thrown attack , a melee attack made against a target within X spaces. Thrown attacks are affected by cover. If throwing a weapon, it lands in a space adjacent to the target (thrower's choice), and must be picked up as a free action while adjacent to it before it can be used again.

Summons have the following statistics unless otherwise indicated:

- Ø SIZE 1/2
- Ø HP 5
- Ø DODGE/A-DEF 10
- Ø SPEED 0
- Ø SAVE TARGET = Summoner's SAVE TARGET
- Ø BULK / AGILITY / MIND / MAGIC 0

Summons can only be created in free spaces that they could normally enter (they can't be summoned into impassable terrain, for example).

Summons are characters with a standard action , standard movement , and minor action per round; however, they can't perform any actions unless they have an ability that lets them do so and can't perform a movement unless they have SPEED . Their turn is their summoner's turn, and if they can take actions or move, they can do so at any point in their summoner's turn.

Summons are defeated if they are reduced to 0 HP. They can also be dismissed by their summoner as a free action . Summons last until dismissed or defeated, or until the end of the scene.

Trap: Abilities with this tag place traps - objects that modify spaces - or are traps themselves. They must be placed in a free adjacent space. They become armed at the end of the turn in which they are placed. Moving into or adjacent to a space occupied by a trap triggers it, activating its effects, after which it is removed from play.

Traps are permanently HIDDEN , but can be automatically detected with SEARCH .  Y ou can attempt to disarm a trap by making an AGILITY check as a minor action when moving into or adjacent to its space (before it is triggered). On a success, the trap is removed from play without being activated. On a failure, it activates as normal.

Unbreakable: Abilities with this tag cannot be destroyed and can't be selected for destruction if there are nonUnbreakable options left. If an Unbreakable result is selected from a wound or overstress roll, it becomes a DAZED result instead.

Unique: Characters can only equip one copy of each ability with this tag at a time.

## 6: ANCESTRIES

## A character's ancestry describes their heritage or species.

Your beacon's ancestry determines their SIZE and gives you a collection of ancestry traits that you can choose from for combat scenes. You select an ancestry for your beacon during character creation (p. 13), and can only change it with the FIND ECHO downtime activity (p. 28).

In narrative play, ancestry can provide whatever abilities or powers work in your Reflection. For example, in your Reflection, elves might be immortal, while machina don't need to eat or sleep. Those are flavorful abilities that impact narrative play, but don't affect combat play unless you pick an ancestry trait that says otherwise.

Ancestry can also be used to represent cultural themes instead of biological ones, and individual ancestries can be reimagined to represent entirely different species. For example, you might choose the elemental ancestry to represent a ghostly, spectral beacon.

This chapter lists the available ancestries for players to choose. Each ancestry contains some questions you can answer to help flesh out the ancestry and your character, as well as an example of a Reflection and discussion of how that ancestry fits within it. As a reminder, one of the things common to all Reflections is the presence of a Scourge - a recurring threat unique to that Reflection (p. 230).

## DUAL AND CUSTOM ANCESTRIES

Some characters might have more than one ancestry, representing two different parts of their background, or a custom one that isn't represented by the existing options.

When playing such a character with a dual ancestry, pick one ancestry as normal; however, you might have abilities in narrative play that stem from the other ancestry.

Additionally, the GM can optionally allow you to base your character's SIZE on one ancestry and create a list of four ancestry traits (two from each ancestry) as your pool of potential ancestry abilities.

Example: Artemis is the child of a halfling and a goblin. She is SIZE 1/2 since both of her parent ancestries are SIZE 1/2 ,  and her player chooses two ancestry traits from each. She chooses NIMBLE ESCAPE and BITE for the goblin heritage, and LUCKY and BRAVE for her halfling heritage. Now, whenever she prepares for a quest, she can choose one of those four ancestry traits.

To create a custom ancestry, start by choosing a SIZE between 1/2 and 3 .  Then, create a pool of any four existing ancestry traits. It is recommended that you choose traits that fit the themes of your custom ancestry, rather than just choosing the abilities you think are strongest.

## ANCESTRIES IN YOUR REFLECTION

Not every ancestry exists in every Reflection. Some Reflections only feature humans, while others have a limited number of ancestries represented.

Just because an ancestry doesn't exist in a setting, doesn't mean you can't use its traits. In an all-human setting, for example, there are huge variances between people. Maybe your human with the goblin ancestry is a small teen, or a group of kids in a trench coat (using the SWARM trait). A human with the avian ancestry might have a magic item that allows them to fly, or could have built a jetpack.

At heart, an ancestry is a set of bonuses for combat play and an important part of the game. Just because there isn't a species in the setting that matches the ancestry, doesn't mean it shouldn't be used. BEACON is a game about choices, and severely restricting the ancestry choices takes away a vital part of combat play.

## In summary:

- Ø ancestry does not have to equal species
- Ø ancestry and ancestry traits only have direct rules effects in combat play
- Ø players shouldn't be overly restricted in choosing ancestries
- Ø your Reflection can have as many or as few ancestries as you want.

## EXAMPLE REFLECTION: GARUDA

Name: Celestos

The celestos of Garuda live atop the highest mountains, where they are bathed in radiant energy from the sky. As a result, they have learned to harness this energy as holy magic.

Celestos place a great emphasis on wings. Those born with additional sets of wings are seen as having great potential. Most celestos have two wings, with four wings being rare and six or more wings almost unheard of.

Some celestos are born with a mutation that causes them to grow an additional pair of arms, but no wings. These celestos find life atop the mountains hard, as their homes aren't designed for the flightless. They usually leave their homes to find a more suitable life among the other flightless civilizations, or take up supportive roles in their homelands.

## FLIGHTLESS CELESTOS

If you want to play a flightless celestos, you can either use the orc ancestry or switch out the avian Flight trait with a trait from the orc ancestry.

## EXAMPLE REFLECTION: IO

## Name: Drakhal

The drakhal of Io primarily dwell in volcanic regions, which run the gamut from barren wastelands to tropical islands teeming with life.

Each group of drakhal are in possession of ancient dragon eggs. These massive eggs must be incubated in the burning temperatures of active volcanos. Each group of drakhal believe they are the inheritors of their specific dragon's legacy, which explains the physical differences between these groups: some have tails, some have wings, some have few scales, and so on.

Inside their eggs, the growing dragons are already named, with names like Bahamut, Phoenix, and Nidhogg. The drakhal believe that when their dragon hatches, it will change the world in their favor. One dragon might destroy all enemies of the drakhal that hatched it, while another might bring prosperity and bountiful harvests across the world. Once the dragon has changed the world, it returns to its lair, where a new shell forms around it, and it waits until its next hatching.

These ancient dragons rarely awaken, and each has their own cycle. It is likely, due to the cyclical nature of these dragons, that one (or more) of them is Io's Scourge .

## EXAMPLE REFLECTION: CONVERGENCE Name: Fewa

The fewa of Convergence live in separate nations based on their associated elements. Two important individuals are always born or created within a few years of each other: the Weaver and the Cultivator .

The Weaver can always manipulate multiple elements. They seek to unify the fewa nations under one banner and one element.

The Cultivator seeks to keep the nations independent, and to grow them individually.

The Weaver and Cultivator are always in conflict with each other, as their purposes and philosophies are opposed. Each approach has benefits and flaws, and each party firmly believes in their role.

To complicate matters, in each cycle one of these two people becomes the Scourge , and there appears to be no pattern as to which one it is.

## EXAMPLE REFLECTION: MONTON Name: Gob

The gobs of Monton sometimes undergo a sudden metamorphosis, rapidly changing their size and abilities. The most common form (and the one they're born into) is that of a basic goblit, which is also the smallest. In their second 'hobgob' stage, they grow in size and strength. The third form is that of the 'bokgob' , which is even stronger and begins to develop wildly varied appearances like fur, extra arms, or a thick hide.

The exact reasons why only some gobs undergo this metamorphosis and why some never progress beyond the goblit stage are unknown. The leading theory is that it's a genetic mutation.

There is rumored to be a stage of metamorphosis beyond bokgob - the 'urgob' stage. There are no recorded cases of urgobs, but if it is stronger than the bokgob stage, it must be incredibly powerful.

## 7: CLASSES AND JOBS

Classes are collections of abilities you unlock over time. Each class has an associated job , which is something you can choose to equip at the beginning of a quest. Jobs grant traits and determine the base values of your attributes.

Classes are thematically connected collections of equipment and techniques that you can equip for quests, and each is associated with a job. The description of each class includes some optional questions to help flesh out your character and their connection to that class.

Each class has three ranks, starting at class rank 1 and going up to class rank 3 . Whenever your beacon levels up , including at level 1, they acquire a new class rank, either gaining a new class at rank 1 or increasing their current rank in a class by one step.

## VARIANT JOBS

Each of the classes in this book have one associated job, which shares the same name as the class; however, future books may introduce variant jobs, and you can always add new jobs in your own games.

For example, this book includes only one job for the Paladin class - also called the Paladin - but a future book might add another job for the Paladin class, called the Avenger. In that case, upon reaching rank 1 in the Paladin class you could choose to unlock either the Paladin job or the Avenger job, but not both.

You unlock one of a class's associated jobs upon reaching rank 1 in that class. Jobs give you access to specific traits and determine the base values for your attributes, like your HP and the number and size of your weapon slots. Once you have unlocked a job, your beacon can equip it whenever they go on a quest. They can only equip one job at a time.

Every rank you have in a class also unlocks two abilities for your character. These abilities can be weapons, support items, spells, or skills. Once an ability is unlocked, it enters the pool of abilities you can equip when you go on a quest.

You aren't limited to equipping techniques and equipment associated with the job you've equipped. In fact, you are encouraged to mix equipment and techniques from both the basic options (p. 216) and all of your unlocked classes.

<!-- image -->

## ELEMENTS OF A JOB

Each job has several elements: a role, base attributes, some traits, weapon slots and support slots of various types, and a limit break.

Role: A job's role describe what sorts of things characters with that job do in combat:

- Ø Artillery: Deals damage over long range.
- Ø Controller: Manipulates foes or the battlefield to gain an advantage.
- Ø Defender: Protects their allies or draws attention to themselves.
- Ø Striker: Deals damage over close-to-medium range.
- Ø Support: Assists allies, either by healing, mitigating damage, or enhancing other characters.

Base Attributes: A character's equipped job determines the starting values for their attributes.

Each attribute is listed beneath an ability score ( BULK , AGILITY , MIND , or MAGIC ). These attributes are modified by the points you have put into the relevant ability score. The values listed for attributes are the starting values, assuming 0 points invested in the related ability score.

- Ø SCOPE: The distance within which you can use certain abilities, such as ranged spell attacks.
- Ø SAVE TARGET: The target number characters have to meet or exceed when rolling a save against you.

## Bulk

- Ø HP: When you reach 0 HP, you take a Wound and make a wound roll. When you reach your WOUND CAP (4), you are defeated.
- Ø RECOVERIES: A resource you can spend to recover HP and repair destroyed equipment and techniques.

## Agility

- Ø DODGE: The number that attackers must equal or exceed to hit you.
- Ø SPEED: The number of spaces you can move with your standard movement.

## Mind

- Ø STRESS CAP: When you exceed your STRESS CAP , you take an Overstress and make an overstress roll. When you reach your OVERSTRESS CAP (4), you are defeated.
- Ø MEMORY: You can equip any number of techniques the combined MEMORY cost of which doesn't exceed your MEMORY .

## Magic

- Ø A-DEF: The number that attackers must equal or exceed to hit you with Aetheric attacks.
- Ø MP: A resource you can spend to use certain abilities.

Traits: Each job has several unique abilities. If you equip a different job, you lose access to the traits from your current job and gain the traits of the new one.

Weapon Slots: Your job determines the number and type of weapon slots available.

Support Slots: Your job determines the number and type of the support item slots available.

Limit Break: Limit breaks are powerful, unique abilities that can be used once per quest.

DEFENDER

Defense-oriented spellcasters adept with protective magic. Aegises put up barriers and shields to protect friends and block out foes.

A egises are defensive spellcasters that specialize in creating barriers and mitigating damage. Aegises rely on efficient use of mana to keep their barriers up for prolonged periods of time, and a group of them can maintain a city-spanning barrier for the duration of a siege.

## BASE ATTRIBUTES

While the primary purpose of an aegis's barriers is protection, they can also be used offensively. A well-placed wall can split a group of enemies or cut off an avenue of attack. For these reasons, aegises find themselves in high demand, especially in militaristic organizations and cities. They are at their strongest when there are people to protect, so they are seldom alone.

Aegises use many methods to extend their mana capacity and lessen the cost of spells: magical tattoos that act as miniature ley lines, mana batteries and potions, and arcane familiars are just some of the tools used by different schools of aegises.

## Dragon Echo ( SIZE 3 , HP = GRIT+15 , DODGE/ A-DEF 10 , SPEED 6 )

You summon an echo of your dragon within RANGE . This dragon has flight and can move up to its SPEED during your turn. Allies can share spaces with it, and any allies fully within its spaces can move with it when it moves. The dragon lasts until the end of the scene or until defeated.

The dragon can also attack with the ECHO WAVE weapon as a standard action during your turn, adding your GRIT to the attack roll.

The bond a dragon rider has with their mount is deep, and requires both creatures to weave their aetheric fields together. Many fail to do this, resulting in a backlash against the creature with the weaker field, which is usually the rider. Aetheric backlashes can cause serious injury or permanent physical changes in the likeness of the more powerful creature.

Once the bond is complete, the rider and dragon become one. The strongest dragon riders can pour their mana into creating an echo of their companion made of pure aether. Even if their dragon companion is long dead, a dragon rider is never alone - their partner will live on inside them.

Equinoxes harness celestial aether to empower their destructive spells. Aether of the sun enhances the explosive potential of spells, and aether of the moon enhances the effective range of spells.

<!-- image -->

E quinoxes pull celestial aether from beyond the bounds of their planet, mixing it with the native aether around them. This celestial aether comes in two types - sun aether and moon aether - though they do not necessarily originate from a literal sun and moon.

Sun aether is dangerous and destructive. Spells empowered with sun aether explode violently. Moon aether, on the other hand, is stable and strong. Spells empowered with moon aether can keep their form over longer distances.

## TRAITS

## Day/Night Cycle

TRAIT

You have two special resources Sun and Moon - that each start at 0. You can only have one of these resources at a time, and they reset to 0 at the end of each combat scene.

- Ø Minor Action: You set your Sun or Moon at 1 (setting the other at 0), or clear all Sun and Moon . If you already have 1 Sun or 1 Moon , you can instead increase it by +1 , to a maximum of 2 .

Sun and Moon have the following effects:

- Ø Sun: For each Sun you have, your AOE spells and artifact weapons gain +1 to their AOEs ( Line AOEs have their width increased by +1, instead); however, you must spend +1 MP each time you use one of these spells or weapons. If you can't, you immediately lose all Sun .
- Ø Moon: For each Moon you have, your SCOPE and RANGE with artifact weapons and spells that have a RANGE increase by +4; however, you take 1 STRESS each time you target something with a spell or artifact weapon attack beyond your normal SCOPE or the weapon's RANGE .

## Mage Tower

TRAIT

If you haven't moved since the start of your last turn, you gain both of the following benefits, which don't stack:

- Ø Surecast: Your ranged artifact weapon and spell attacks gain +1 .
- Ø Sharpcast: Your CHANNEL spells impose +1 on any saves they trigger.

You create two SIZE 3 gateways on free solid surfaces within RANGE 15 , ignoring line of sight. These gateways aren't obstructions, don't block line of sight, and last until the end of the scene.

1/turn when a character fully enters a gateway, they are immediately teleported to the other gateway, being placed in a space of their choice so they are fully within the gateway. Shapeshifters are able to assume various forms to overcome obstacles, transforming their entire body or individual parts as needed.

S hapeshifters can change their bodies, taking on the features of other creatures or changing into different creatures altogether. The earliest shapeshifters were lycanthropes studying the way their transformations worked. Over time, they discovered how to transform specific parts of their bodies, and eventually how to choose what they transformed into.

This type of shapeshifting is notable because it's a learned skill, not a spell. The shapeshifter carefully rearranges their aetheric balance until it precisely aligns with the typical aetheric balance of the creature they're shapeshifting into. While their form may be different, they're still the same person they were before. A shapeshifter that transforms into a bear isn't actually a bear; they're merely adopting the outward form of a bear.

Tidecallers command the oceans and waters. They can manipulate currents to reposition allies and hinder enemies.

C ommon wisdom suggests that only a fool braves the seas without a tidecaller. Their command over water and their insight into weather patterns make them invaluable additions to any seafaring vessel.

## BASE ATTRIBUTES

Tidecallers are strongly associated with water-aspect aether, known for its healing properties. A drop of this magical water can heal a small cut, while a deluge can repair deadly wounds and restore vitality. An often-forgotten aspect of water-aspect aether is its weight. Surprisingly, small quantities can knock a grown person off their feet and drag them around in its wake.

Talents are bundles of abilities you can learn that aren't tied to specific classes. Each talent has three ranks. Beacons start with three talents at rank 1 .

## AETHERBENDER

Your  magical  expertise  gives  you  insight  into  the manipulation of spells for different effects.

## Rank 1: Aetheric Upgrade

You can apply the following effects to your spells. Each spell can only be affected by one at a time:

- Ø Far Spell: When you use a spell, you can spend 1 MP to do so with +5 RANGE .
- Ø Fast Spell: During your turn, you can use VOLLEY or FIGHT spells during earlier phases, but no earlier than PHASE BOLSTER . For each phase earlier than its normal phase, you spend 1 MP .
- Ø Quiet Spell: When you use a spell while HIDDEN , you can spend 2 MP to remain HIDDEN after the spell resolves.

## Rank 2: Advanced Aetheric Upgrade

You add the following effects to your AETHERIC UPGRADES options:

- Ø Flexible Spell: When you make a spell attack, you can spend 1 MP to change the defense that it targets ( DODGE or A-DEF ).
- Ø Empowered Spell: When you use a spell that involves a save, you can spend 2 MP to impose +1 on any saves it causes.
- Ø Repeated Spell: When you make a non-AOE spell attack, you can spend 3 MP to attack two targets. They must be within RANGE 5 of each other and within your SCOPE .

## Rank 3: Aether Mixer

You can apply two different AETHERIC UPGRADE at once, spending the MP for each effect.

Additionally, you gain 1 MP spell attack.

options when you crit with a

Talents come in three ranks: rank 1 , rank 2 , and rank 3 . Ranks must be taken in order; you need rank 1 in a talent to take rank 2, and you need rank 2 to take rank 3. When you level up, you can increase the rank of an existing talent or gain a new one at rank 1.

Once you have a talent, its effects are always available to you.

## ARCHMAGE

Archmages stand at the pinnacle of aetheric research. They manipulate magic in ways that others can only dream of.

## Rank 2: Arcane Turret

- Ø When you are channeling, you gain +2 ARMOR , to a maximum of 4 .
- Ø Taking Stress doesn't trigger concentration saves .

## Rank 3: Focused Caster

## ARMORED DEFENDER

Armor  keeps  you  alive.  The  stronger  and  more reliable your armor is, the longer you stay alive.

## Rank 1: Reinforced Plating

After you DEFEND , you can spend FOCUS , temporarily gaining +1 ARMOR per FOCUS spent, to a maximum of 6 ARMOR .  This lasts until the start of your next turn or until you next take Physical, Astral, Lunar, or Force.

## Rank 2: Adamantine Armor

## Rank 3: Battle Hardened

## COMMANDER

The  difference  between  a  good  commander  and  a bad one is trust. A bad commander issues orders and expects them to be followed because of their rank. A good commander knows their troops and trusts them to follow orders, and the team trusts the commander to keep them alive.

## Rank 1: Commander's Mark

When you make a character MARKED , you can make it a special Commander's Mark . It functions as a normal MARK , but when an ally consumes it, you roll a 1d6: on a 5+, the target stays MARKED with the Commander's Mark. You can only have one Commander's Mark at a time; placing a new one turns the old one into a normal MARK .

## Rank 2: Planning

When an ally uses the Strain option from the Reroll Table on an attack against a character with your COMMANDER'S MARK , the Stress cost is reduced by 1. Additionally, your Commander's Marks remain on a result of 4+ instead of a 5+.

## Rank 3: Order

1/round when you make a character MARKED , you can announce an action that you want any ally to take against that target. The first ally that takes that action against the target while they are MARKED gains TEMP HP equal to your GRIT+2 .

## COPYCAT

Copycats possess the rare ability to mimic the abilities of  others.  Those  in  possession  of  metamorphic  ore can even copy the equipment of their enemies.

## Rank 1: Scan

You can SEARCH as a minor action .

## Rank 2: Copy

When you SEARCH an enemy to learn about their ability scores, attributes, and abilities, you can spend 1 MP to gain access to one of those pieces of equipment or techniques until the end of the scene. You can only copy one thing at a time.

## Rank 3: Imitate

Copy can now be used to gain access to enemy traits, and you can copy up to two things at once.

Additionally, when an enemy uses a piece of equipment, technique, or trait within your line of sight, you can spend 1 MP to gain access to it until the end of the scene.

The COPYCAT talent is intended for fun, casual play only. It's not intended to be balanced. Check with your GM to see if they want this talent to be used.

## DEADEYE

Everyone knows that you're better off hitting a specific body part than lashing out blindly, but it's incredibly difficult to put that knowledge into practice during a real fight. Those with the speed, skill, and accuracy to reliably do so can end fights quickly.

## Rank 1: Precision

## Rank 2: Body Parts

1/round when you crit on an attack roll, you can choose to deal half damage and apply one of the following additional effects:

- Ø Foot: The target is IMMOBILIZED until the end of their next turn.
- Ø Head: The target is DAZED until the end of their next turn.
- Ø Leg: The target is SLOWED until the end of their next turn.

- Ø Eye: The target is BLINDED until the end of their next turn.

## ENCHANTER

Infusing items with aetheric energy allows you to grant them unique traits. Enchanted weapons are always better than their mundane counterparts.

- Ø Any Weapon, Skill Attack, or Spell Attack that deals Discord: On a crit with this ability, you deal +1 Discord .

## Aspected SUPPORT ITEM  ENCHANTMENT

You may use one of the following Enchantments at a time:

- Ø Any Armor: You gain +1 to checks and saves with one ability score BULK , AGILITY , MIND , or MAGIC -chosen when you apply this Enchantment.
- Ø Any Equipment or Technique: When you attack with this ability, you can spend 1 MP to give it the Aetheric tag, or to remove it. This change lasts for the rest of the scene or until you use this ability again.

ent

## MAGI-TECHNICIAN

Magitech  weapons  utilize  technology  to  mimic  the effects  of  traditional  spells,  letting  anyone  harness the destructive power of magic. Different civilizations have created their own power sources for magitech, from electrical currents through to soul gems.

## Rank 1: Growing Power

Whenever you crit with a magitech weapon, you get a d6 Power Die .  Y ou can have up to 6 Power Dice, which last until the end of a quest or until spent.

After rolling an attack or damage roll with a magitech weapon, you can roll any number of Power Dice, expending them in the process. The highest number rolled is added to the result of the attack roll or to the damage roll as bonus damage.

## Rank 2: Infused Ammo

When you attack with a magitech weapon, you can spend up to 6 MP to increase the attack's existing Physical, Force, Astral, or Lunar by +1 per MP spent. The increased damage applies to every target hit by the attack.

## Rank 3: Unstable Power Core

1/round when you crit with a magitech weapon, you can apply one of the following effects:

- Ø Magnetic: The target is DISARMED until the end of their next turn.
- Ø Shielded: You gain 2 FOCUS .
- Ø Shock: The target is DAZED and SLOWED until the end of their next turn.
- Ø Soul Gem: The target is WEAKENED until the end of their next turn and MARKED .
- Ø Volatile: The target is SUNDERED until the end of their next turn and knocked PRONE .

## SAVAGE FIGHTER

In the face of unbridled savagery, most training and discipline finds itself lacking.

You can deploy in any free space within RANGE 5 of an edge of the map.

## SLASHER

## Rank 1: Feint

For example, if a blade attack deals 10 PHYSICAL , you can choose to have it deal 5 PHYSICAL + 5 DISCORD instead.

## Rank 2: Zero In

When you miss with a ranged attack, you gain +1 on all ranged attacks until you hit with one. This effect stacks.

## Rank 3: Pinpoint Shot

1/round when you crit with a ranged attack while IMMOBILIZED , you deal +1d6 bonus damage .

## SOLDIER

A versatile soldier must be consistent and reliable in any situation.

## Rank 1: Weapon Focus

The first time each turn you perform a melee attack with a MAIN weapon, that attack gains +1 .

## Rank 2: Stances

Minor Action: You take 1 STRESS and enter one of the following stances Wolf Stance , Snake Stance , or Eagle Stance .  Y ou remain in this stance for the rest of the scene or until you perform this minor action again. You may enter each stance 1/scene.

When you enter a stance, you gain a d6 Stance Die that starts at 6. After attacking with a MAIN melee weapon, reduce the value of your Stance Die by -2. If it reaches 0, you drop the stance.

- Ø Wolf Stance: Your MAIN melee weapon attacks gain Reliable X ,  where X is the value of your Stance Die. The Reliable damage can't exceed the weapon's maximum damage.
- Ø Snake Stance: The ARMOR of your targets can't reduce the damage of your MAIN melee weapon attacks below the value of your Stance Die.
- Ø Eagle Stance: Before rolling an attack with a MAIN melee weapon, you can do either of the following:
-  Treat one die as if it had rolled the value of your Stance Die.
-  Treat one die as if it had rolled 7 minus the value of your Stance Die. For example, if your Stance Die is 4, you could treat the result of a die as 3 (7 - 4 = 3).

## Rank 3: Practiced

Instead of reducing your Stance Die by -2 after attacking with a MAIN melee weapon, you only reduce it by -1.

Additionally, the following option is added to your

## Reroll Table :

## SPEEDSTER

Go  fast.  Embrace  speed.  Put  your  problems  behind you, and never stop running, or they'll catch you.

Sonidos last between scenes, but reset to 0 during each Long Rest .

When you RUSH , you can use both options instead of choosing one.
