## Aether Flask

MINOR ACTION

SUPPORT ITEM (UNCOMMON)  LIGHT  CONSUMABLE 2

Drinking this potion suffuses you with aetheric energies until the end of your next turn. You can expend a charge to receive all of the following effects:

- Ø You cannot attack or use spells.
- Ø You are immune to Physical, Astral, and Lunar .
- Ø You can move through solid objects as if they were difficult terrain , but you can't end a turn inside one. If you end a turn inside or partly inside an object, you are moved to the last free space you moved through that turn.

## Aether Shield SPELL (RARE)  1 MEMORY  MANA X, UNIQUE

When you would take damage (after ARMOR and resistances ), you can spend MP to reduce the damage taken. You take -2 damage for every 1 MP spent. This spell can't reduce Piercing damage or Discord , and can't be used if you are incapable of taking reactions .

## Agile Discord SKILL (RARE)  1 MEMORY

You can use AGILITY instead of MAGIC when making checks to clear Discord .

## Aid

## REACTION (1/ROUND)

SPELL (UNCOMMON)  1 MEMORY  MANA 1

Trigger: An ally within SCOPE makes an ability check or save.

Effect: You grant them +1 on the check or save.

## Ammo Kit MINOR ACTION

SUPPORT ITEM (UNCOMMON)  MAIN  CONSUMABLE 2

You or an adjacent ally can expend a charge to reload a single weapon.

## GENERAL TERMINOLOGY

Ancestry: Ancestry describes a beacon's heritage or species. It determines their SIZE and gives access to a list of ancestry traits . Whenever a beacon goes on a quest, they can choose to equip one of their ancestry traits.

Boss: The toughest enemies in the game are Bosses. Bosses have their own unique rules for combat.

Battle Plan: Battle plans provide the framework for combat scenes, determining the win conditions for the PCs, the NPC budget, and any special rules.

Class: Classes represent specialized approaches to combat. Classes unlock equipment and abilities that beacons can equip for quests. Each class has three ranks, with each rank unlocking additional equipment and abilities.

Hub: A base of operations for beacons.

Job: Jobs provide the starting values for a beacon's attributes and their equipment slots. A class's job is unlocked upon reaching rank 1 in that class.

Level/Character Level: Each beacon has a character level , which represents their overall growth and strength. Whenever you finish a quest, whether you were successful or not, your beacon gains another character level. The maximum character level for beacons is 12.

Loot: Loot includes a range of equipment and techniques that aren't tied to specific classes. It is usually presented to the players via loot crates . Loot is categorized by rarity. It can be Uncommon , Rare , or Legendary .

Loot Crate: A loot crate is a set of three random pieces of loot from which the player can select one to keep.

Non-Player Character (NPC): Characters controlled by the GM are called non-player characters , or NPCs. NPCs can be friends, foes, beasts, or anything else that the GM presents.

NPC Template: T emplates are additional sets of features that can be added to NPCs, which can drastically alter how they play. There are two types of templates: thematic and mechanical .

NPC Tier: NPCs come in one of three tiers: tier 1 ( T1 ), tier 2 ( T2 ), and tier 3 ( T3 ). NPCs of higher tiers are stronger and tougher than those of lower tiers.

NPC Type: NPC types are collections of abilities and attributes that represent general themes, similar to player character jobs.

Quest: Quests are adventures that beacons go on, each comprising a combination of narrative and combat play.

Reflection: The many settings of BEACON . Each setting is called a Reflection.

Resting: Resting allows PCs to heal, recover resources, and repair equipment. There are two types of rests: Short Rests and Long Rests . Short Rests are quick breaks that allow beacons to patch themselves up after a fight, while Long Rests are longer and more restorative.

Title: All beacons have a title, which can be used during narrative play to gain a +2 bonus to a skill check.

## NARRATIVE TERMINOLOGY

Adversity Challenge: A type of skill challenge representing the obstacles the beacons encounter between combat scenes, like moving through dangerous rooms in a dungeon or sneaking past patrolling guards to ambush a target.

Background Skills: Words or brief phrases that represent a beacon's history and training. Background skills have three ranks. Skill checks use background skills, and grant +1 on the roll for reach rank in the skill.

Downtime Activity: When beacons have free time, they can perform downtime activities.

Narrative Action: Narrative actions are a type of skill check with specific outcomes.

Skill Challenge: Skill challenges are series of rapid skill checks. Skill challenges can be split into two categories: story challenges and adversity challenges .

Skill Check: Skills checks are used to determine success during narrative play.

Story Challenge: A type of skill challenge. Story challenges are used when an obstacle or scene is too complex to be resolved with a single skill check.

## COMBAT TERMINOLOGY

Ability: All techniques, traits, and equipment. Basically, if something does something in combat, it's an ability.

Ability Check/Save: A roll made to overcome an obstacle or resist an effect. Effects that prompt ability checks or saves indicate which ability score BULK , AGILITY , MIND , or MAGIC is used for the roll. Background skills, GRIT , and titles don't apply. To succeed on an ability check , you need a result of 10+. To succeed on a save , your result must equal or exceed the SAVE TARGET of the initiator, or 10 if not otherwise specified.

Ability Scores: The four ability scores BULK, AGILITY, MIND, MAGIC - affect a character's attributes and actions in combat play.

Ally: A character friendly to you or on the same side. You don't count as your own ally.

Area of Effect (AOE): Abilities and effects with an AOE affect multiple targets or spaces. Blast , Burst , Close Blast , and Line are types of AOEs.

Attack: Attempts by characters to hit and harm something with weapons, magic, or other means. To hit your target, your result must equal or exceed their defense (either DODGE or A-DEF , depending on the type of attack). Attacks can be either melee attacks or ranged attacks , and can be further categorized as weapon, spell, support, or skill attacks.

Attribute: Beacons have several attributes that are used in combat play, such as DODGE and SIZE .  These scores are determined by a character's level, job, ancestry, talents, ability scores, equipment, and techniques.

Bonus Damage: Additional damage added onto an existing source of damage. Effects with more than one target only deal half their bonus damage to each target. Only successful attacks or abilities that deal damage can deal bonus damage.

Character: PCs, Summons , and NPCs are all considered characters. As a general rule, characters are entities capable of taking some sort of actions, either personally or at the command of other characters.

Climbing: A special form of movement that allows characters to move atop objects such as terrain. Climbing has a movement cost equal to the object's SIZE + 1 . Characters standing atop objects are considered to have their SIZE increased by the SIZE of whatever they are standing on for the purposes of determining line of sight and cover (p. 49).

aPPendiceS

<!-- image -->

Concentration Save: While channeling, if you take any damage (after ARMOR ) or Stress not caused by yourself, you must pass a BULK save against the initiator's SAVE TARGET . On a failure, you stop channeling and the action is lost.

Cover: Objects on the battlefield can provide cover. Cover imposes on attacks and can block line of sight, depending on whether it is hard cover or soft cover . Soft cover grants +1 to attacks, but doesn't block line of sight. Hard cover grants +2 to attacks and can block line of sight.

Critical Hit: On a result of 20+, an attack roll is a crit . Roll all damage dice twice and take the highest result.

Damage: Harm done to another character. Damage is subtracted from HP , and comes in different types (Physical, Force, Astral, Lunar, Discord).

Dangerous Terrain: Terrain that can cause damage. 1/round when you enter dangerous terrain or end your turn in it, you must make an ability check of the GM's choice. Failure: Y ou take 5 damage of any type or Stress based on the type of terrain.

Defeat: When a beacon is defeated, all effects on them and that originated from them are removed, including Summons . Damage, conditions, statuses, and created objects and terrain remain, including Traps .

Difficult Terrain: Terrain that slows movement. It has +1 movement cost.

Discord X: Discord is a special effect that applies ongoing damage. A character or object that takes Discord immediately takes Piercing discord damage equal to the amount of Discord gained. The Discord they took is then added to any Discord they already have. At the end of each turn while they have Discord, the character or object makes a MAGIC check. On a successful save, all Discord is cleared from them. On a failure, they take Piercing discord damage equal to their current Discord. For more information on Discord, see p. 58.

Enemy: A character that is hostile to you or on the other side.

Environmental Factors: Effects that alter combat scenes, individual spaces, or even objects. Some apply to the entire combat scene, while others affect characters in smaller areas.

Equipment: Weapons and support items are equipment.

Flight: Characters with flight can activate or deactivate the FLYING status 1/turn as a free action.

Forced Movement: Any involuntary movement that pushes , pulls , or slides a character. Forced movements do not provoke reactions and ignore ENGAGEMENT .  Y ou can't be forcibly moved into a space you can't enter.

Free Action: Free actions can only be taken during your turn, but you can perform any number of free actions during that turn.

Grit: An attribute representing the combat experience that beacons gain when they increase their character level. Starting at character level 2 and then at every second level after that (i.e., levels 4, 6, 8, etc.), beacons gain +1 GRIT . GRIT is a passive bonus that applies to several other attributes.

Immunity: When a character is immune to something, they are unaffected by that type of effect.

Initiative: NPCs take their turns in a different way than PCs. Instead of acting based on the phase of the standard action they want to perform, each NPC has an INITIATIVE , which ranges from 1-8. This specifies the phase in which they take their turn. During that phase, the NPC can take any action, not only those options available to PCs during that phase.

Limit Break: Every job has a limit break, which is a power, scene-changing ability unique to that job. Beacons can only perform one limit break per quest.

Line of Sight: All abilities require a clear path to their target, known as line of sight.

Linked Weapons: Two weapons can be linked together to form a linked pair .  When you attack with a linked weapon, you can also attack with the weapon it's linked to as a part of the same action. This is called a linked attack, and each linked pair can only make 1 linked attack per turn (p. 16).

Minor Action: Y ou can perform one minor action during your turn. Minor actions can be used during any phase.

Movement/Standard Movement: You can use your standard movement to move a number of spaces equal to your SPEED .

Object : Anything that isn't a character (or part of one). The terrain, parts of the environment, and deployed items (like Traps ) are all objects.

Obstruction: If a character or object is the same SIZE as you or larger, you can't move through their spaces. Allied characters and enemy characters smaller than you don't count as obstructions and you can move through their spaces, but you can't end a movement sharing spaces with another character.

Phase: The various stages of the round during which characters can act. The phase in which a character takes a turn is usually decided by the action they want to perform, as each action can only be performed in a specific phase.

Range/Reach: The maximum number of spaces within which a given ability can be used. Range and Reach work in the same way, but some effects trigger based on one or the other, not both.

Reaction: Special actions performed in response to specific triggers, even on other character's turns. You can perform one reaction per turn, but there is no limit on how many times a specific reaction can be used unless one is specified.

Reroll Table: When making an attack, ability check, or save in combat , you can reroll the dice by using the Reroll Table . To use the table, you choose one of the listed options and reroll all dice for one roll (including or ). Each option from the table can only be chosen once per round (p. 52).

Resistance: Reduces damage by half.

Round: Each combat scene is made up of a number of rounds , each of which is split up into eight distinct phases . At the end of the eighth phase, the round ends and another round begins.

Shift: A special movement that doesn't provoke reactions and ignores ENGAGEMENT . You can't shift if you are SLOWED or IMMOBILIZED .

Scene: An entire combat, from beginning to end. Once the fighting is over, the scene ends.

Squeezing: A special form of movement that allows characters to fit into spaces one SIZE smaller than them, but increases the cost of all movements by +1 while doing so (p. 55).

Standard Action: Characters can take one standard action per turn. Beacons can only use standard actions from the current phase.

Stress: A special type of harm that doesn't count as damage and doesn't affect the recipient's HP . Stress accumulates up to a character's STRESS CAP .

Surging: Beacons can surge 1/round to take a second turn at the cost of taking Stress (p. 42).

Talent: Sets of abilities that don't need to be equipped. Once your beacon has learned a talent, they will always have access to any abilities unlocked by their ranks in that talent. Each talent has three ranks.

Techniques: Skills and spells are techniques.

Teleport: A special form of movement that allows for instant movement between two spaces. Teleportation doesn't require line of sight, doesn't provoke reactions , and ignores ENGAGEMENT .  T eleportation always counts as moving 1 space. If a character teleports into a space they can't occupy, the teleport fails and the action is lost.

Terrain: A specific subset of object that includes the environmental elements in a combat scene - trees, walls, rocks, and similar.

Terrain Features: Terrain features modify spaces and terrain on the battlefield. While they generally affect single spaces, multiple terrain features can be placed next to each other to create a continuous feature.

Trait: Abilities that reinforce a beacon's identity and playstyle. Traits come from a beacon's ancestry and equipped job.

Turns: Each character takes one turn per round, taken during one of that round's phases. The action they want to take on their turn determines which phase they act in. On their turn, a character can perform their standard movement , one standard action , one minor action , and any number of free actions (within reason). Most NPCs only take one turn per round, but some NPCs might take multiple turns.

Wound/Overstress: Characters can receive Wounds or become Overstressed . As they accumulate Wounds and Overstresses, their combat performance weakens until they are no longer able to fight.

Zone: A lingering effect from an AOE, which remains in play for a set time or until the end of the scene.

## TAGS

Accurate: Attacks with this tag gain +1 .

Aetheric: Attacks with this tag are made against A-Def instead of Dodge.

Arcing: Abilities with this tag can be aimed over obstacles. They ignore line of sight as long as there is a vertical path to the target, although cover still applies.

Armor: Abilities with this tag represent suits of armor or similar defenses, many of which provide a bonus to ARMOR . A character can only have one ability with this tag equipped at a time.

Aura X: When activated, abilities with this tag affect indicated characters within X spaces of the user. A character can only have one Aura activated at a time and can change Auras 1/turn.

Auto-Hit: Attacks with this tag automatically hit without making an attack roll.

Blast X: Abilities with this tag have an AOE. It affects all targets within a radius of X spaces from the center space, including the center space . Cover and line of sight are calculated from the center space. Users can be affected by their own Blast.

Burst X: Affects all targets within a radius of X spaces from the edge of the spaces occupied by the target, including the target's spaces but excluding the target itself . Cover and line of sight are calculated from the edge of the spaces occupied by the target. If a Burst forms a zone , the zone moves with the target.

Close Blast X: Abilities with this tag have an AOE. It operates like a Blast , but:

-  at least 1 space must be adjacent to the user
-  the user can't be in the area
-  cover and line of sight are calculated from the user.

Consumable X: Abilities with this tag can only be used X times per quest. Consumable abilities represent potions, elixirs, and other items that can be replenished.

Enchantment: Abilities with this tag modify other abilities. Enchantments can typically only be applied to specific types of abilities and can only be applied to one ability at a time. Additionally, each ability can only have one Enchantment at a time. Enchantments can only be applied to a new ability while preparing for a quest or during a Long Rest.

If an Enchantment is destroyed, the ability it is enchanting is not destroyed and vice versa. Traits and talents can't be enchanted.

Focus X: Abilities with this tag cost X FOCUS to use.

Homing: Abilities with this tag ignore line of sight and the effects of cover. As long as the target is within Range and it is possible to reach them (i.e., they aren't in a box), they can be targeted.

Inaccurate: Attacks with this tag receive +1 .

Indirect: Attacks with this tag ignore any from cover.

Innate: Abilities with this tag can't be destroyed or enchanted. They can't be chosen for destruction as the result of a wound roll.

Limited X: Abilities with this tag can only be used X times per quest. Limited abilities provide powerful effects that can't be replenished during a quest once used.

Line X: Abilities with this tag have an AOE. It affects all targets in a straight line with a length of X spaces and a width of 1 space, drawn directly away from you in any direction.

Mana X: Abilities with this tag cost X MP to use.

Polymorph: Abilities with this tag modify the target's form. A character can only be under the effect of one ability with this tag at a time, and any subsequent polymorph effects are automatically cancelled while they are under the effects of a polymorph.

Piercing: Damage with this tag ignores ARMOR .

Pull X: Abilities with this tag inflict a type of forced movement. On a hit, the target is moved X spaces directly toward the origin.

Push X: Abilities with this tag inflict a type of forced movement. On a hit, the target is moved X spaces directly away from the origin.

Range X: Abilities with this tag can be used on targets within X spaces.

Reach X: Abilities with this tag can be used on targets within X spaces. This tag also determines the range of the OPPORTUNITY ATTACK reaction.

Recharge X: Whenever an NPC uses a Recharge ability, it can't be used again until that ability recharges. At the start of each of the NPC's turns after using a Recharge ability, the NPC rolls a d6 recharge die . If the result equals or exceeds the Recharge value (X) of any Recharge abilities they have, those abilities recharge. NPCs only make one recharge roll each turn, but that roll can recharge multiple abilities at once.

Reliable X: Abilities with this tag always deal at least X damage , even if they would miss or deal less than X damage . Reliable damage inherits the ability's damage type and tags; however, Reliable damage does not count as a hit and doesn't trigger any effects that require a hit.

Reloading: Abilities with this tag must be reloaded after each use before they can be used again. This can be done using REFRESH and other abilities.

Slide X: Abilities with this tag inflict a type of forced movement. On a hit, the target is moved X spaces in any direction.

Slow: Abilities with this tag can only be activated as part of FULL ATTACK .

Stressful X: Abilities with this tag inflict X Stress on the user.

Summon: Abilities with this tag create one or more temporary characters under the control of another character, each of which has the Summon tag. Summons have the following statistics unless otherwise indicated:

Basic Summon ( SIZE 1/2 , HP 5 , DODGE/A-DEF 10 , SPEED 0 , SAVE TARGET = Summoner's SAVE TARGET , BULK/AGILITY/MIND/MAGIC 0 )

Summons can only be created in free spaces that they could normally enter (they can't be summoned into impassable terrain, for example).

Summons are characters with a standard action , standard movement , and minor action per round; however, they can't perform any actions unless they have an ability that lets them do so and can't perform a movement unless they have Speed. Their turn is their summoner's turn, and if they can take actions or move, they can do so at any point in their summoner's turn.

Summons are defeated if they are reduced to 0 HP. They can also be dismissed by their summoner as a free action . Summons last until dismissed or defeated, or until the end of the scene.

By default, each character can only have one Summon per ability with this tag in play at a time. If a Summon is defeated or dismissed, a new one can be made using that same ability. Summons can't create Summons.

Thrown X: Abilities with this tag can be used to make a thrown attack , a melee attack made against a target within X spaces. Thrown attacks are affected by cover. If throwing a weapon, it lands in a space adjacent to the target (thrower's choice), and must be picked up as a free action while adjacent to it before it can be used again.

Trap: Abilities with this tag place traps - objects that modify spaces - or are traps themselves. They must be placed in a free adjacent space. They become armed at the end of the turn in which they are placed. Moving into or adjacent to a space occupied by a trap triggers it, activating its effects, after which it is removed from play.

Traps are permanently HIDDEN , but can be automatically detected with SEARCH .  Y ou can attempt to disarm a trap by making an AGILITY check as a minor action when moving into or adjacent to its space (before it is triggered). On a success, the trap is removed from play without being activated. On a failure, it activates as normal.

Unbreakable: Abilities with this tag cannot be destroyed and can't be selected for destruction if there are nonUnbreakable options left. If an Unbreakable result is selected from a wound or overstress roll, it becomes a DAZED result instead.

Unique: Characters can only equip one copy of each ability with this tag at a time.

## COMBAT QUICK GUIDE

Combat takes place within combat scenes . Each combat is made up of a number of rounds . By default, each PC beacon and each NPC takes one turn each round.

<!-- image -->

## COMBAT STRUCTURE

Each round is broken up into eight phases . Characters take their turns in one of these phases. The phase determines which standard actions can be performed.

| PHASE      | STANDARD ACTIONS   | STANDARD ACTIONS   | STANDARD ACTIONS   |
|------------|--------------------|--------------------|--------------------|
| BOLSTER    | Defend             | Defend             | Refresh            |
| CHANNEL    | Channel            | Channel            | Channel            |
| SKIRMISH   | Mark               | Search             | Volley             |
| REPOSITION | Rush               | Rush               | Hide               |
| BRAWL      | Fight              | Shove              | Grapple            |
| RELEASE    | Release            | Release            | Release            |
| FULLATTACK | Full Attack        | Full Attack        | Full Attack        |
| DELAY      | Delay              | Delay              | Delay              |
| ANYPHASE   | Ready              | Ready              | Ready              |

## Player Turns

You take your turn each round during one of the eight phases. During your turn, you can do the following in any order:

<!-- image -->

You can only take standard actions available in the current phase.

## Order

Each round starts with PHASE BOLSTER , and ends with PHASE DELAY .

PCs and NPCs alternate turns. If a PC decides to take their turn during PHASE , then an NPC has the chance to take the next turn in that phase. If no one else takes a turn that phase, the next phase begins. The pattern of alternating turns continues across phases and rounds. This means that if the final turn in a round is taken by a PC, an NPC will have the first opportunity to act in the next round.

At the end of PHASE , a new round begins, starting at PHASE .

## REROLL TABLE

PCs can choose to reroll attacks, checks, and saves during combat, choosing from a list of penalties. This is called using the Reroll Table .

Each option on the Reroll Table can only be used 1/round.

## REROLL TABLE

| STRAIN     | You take 1d3 Stress .                                                                                                                                                        |
|------------|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| ENDANGER   | You become MARKED . You can't use this option if you are MARKED . This doesn't count as a condition that you've given yourself.                                              |
| OVEREXTEND | Youcanonly choose this option if you are adjacent to an enemy or within REACH of an enemy's weapon. The enemycanchooseoneofthefollow- ing, which resolves before you reroll: |

- Ø They  make  an OPPORTUNITY ATTACK against you.
- Ø They deal 3 PHYSICAL to you as a reaction .

## SURGE

Each PC can SURGE once per round, allowing them to take a second turn. This costs a certain amount of Stress based on their SURGE level, which increases each time they SURGE and resets when they next take a Long Rest. This second turn counts as a brand-new turn, giving them a new standard action, standard movement, and minor action.

The Stress cost for surging is listed below. This Stress is taken at the start of a SURGE turn, before anything else. The cost does not progress past 1d6+4.

## STANDARD ACTIONS

Phase 1: Bolster

## Defend

PHASE BOLSTER

You gain FOCUS equal to your ARMOR+1D3 . Until the start of your next turn, attacks against you are made with +1 .

## Refresh

## PHASE BOLSTER

Choose one of the following:

- Ø Spend a RECOVERY to regain all HP .
- Ø Clear all Stress .
- Ø Regain all MP .

Then choose one of the following:

- Ø Reload all Reloading weapons/abilities.
- Ø Clear all Discord .
- Ø Clear a condition that wasn't caused by yourself.
- Ø Clear a condition on an adjacent ally that wasn't caused by them.

Phase 2: Channel

|   SURGE LEVEL | STRESS COST    |
|---------------|----------------|
|             0 | 2 Stress .     |
|             1 | 1d3+1 Stress . |
|             2 | 1d6+2 Stress . |
|             3 | 1d6+4 Stress . |

## Channel

## PHASE CHANNEL

You begin to enact a CHANNEL ability, the effect of which you can unleash in PHASE with the RELEASE action. This is the only way to trigger a channeled ability's RELEASE effect. Until you release it, you are considered to be channeling.

While channeling, if you take any damage (after ARMOR ) or Stress not caused by yourself, you must pass a BULK save against the other character's SAVE TARGET . This is called a concentration save . On a failure, you lose concentration : you stop channeling and the ability fizzles.

You can only channel one ability at a time, and you can't READY the CHANNEL action. You can stop channeling as a free action . If you don't make a standard movement this turn, you can do so when you RELEASE the ability this round.

CHANNEL abilities are considered to be used at the time this action is taken, and any costs (e.g., MP ) must be paid at that time. Their effects, including choosing targets, only happen when they're released unless the ability specifically states they happen when channeling.

## Phase 3: Skirmish

| Mark PHASE SKIRMISH                                                |

| A character within your SCOPE and line of sight be- comes MARKED . |

## Search

## PHASE SKIRMISH

Choose a character or object within SCOPE and pick one:

- Ø If they are HIDDEN , you make a contested MIND check against their AGILITY . On a success, they are no longer HIDDEN .
- Ø You learn the target's ability scores, attributes, and abilities.

## Volley

## PHASE SKIRMISH

You make one of the following attacks:

- Ø Ranged attack: Make a ranged attack with an ability against a target within the ability's RANGE . Roll 1D20+GRIT . If your result meets or exceeds the target's DODGE (or A-DEF for Aetheric attacks), it hits.
- Ø Improvised spell attack ( 1 MP ): Make an Aetheric ranged spell attack against a character within SCOPE . Roll 1D20+GRIT . If your result meets or exceeds the target's A-DEF , they take 2 STRESS .

## Phase 4: Reposition

## Hide

You become HIDDEN .

## Rush

PHASE

REPOSITION

## PHASE REPOSITION

Choose one of the following:

- Ø You move up to your SPEED .
- Ø Until the end of the turn, you ignore ENGAGEMENT and don't provoke reactions from movement.

## Phase 5: Brawl

## Fight

PHASE BRAWL

You make one of the following attacks:

- Ø Melee attack: Make a melee attack with an ability against a target within the ability's REACH . Roll 1D20+GRIT . If your result equals or exceeds the target's DODGE (or A-DEF for Aetheric attacks), it hits.
- Ø Improvised weapon attack: Make a melee weapon attack against an adjacent. Roll 1D20+GRIT . If your result equals or exceeds the target's DODGE , they take 1D3 PHYSICAL .

## Grapple

You make a grapple attack:

- Ø Grapple attack: Make a melee weapon attack against an adjacent character. Roll 1D20+GRIT . If your result equals or exceeds the target's DODGE , you and the target are both GRAPPLED .

Grapple attacks can be made while you are DISARMED (p. 62).

## Shove

You make a shove attack:

- Ø Shove attack: Make a melee weapon attack against an adjacent target. Roll 1D20+GRIT .  Y ou gain +1 for every SIZE you are larger than the target, or +1 for every SIZE smaller. If your result equals or exceeds the target's DODGE , choose one of the following:
-  You push them 1 space .
-  You knock them PRONE .

Shove attacks can be made while you are DISARMED (p. 62).

PHASE

BRAWL

PHASE BRAWL

## Phase 6: Release

## Release

## PHASE RELEASE

You release an ability you are channeling, causing it to take effect. This is resolved as if you were taking a turn, following the rules for alternating turns between PCs and NPCs, but doesn't count as a turn. Instead of releasing an effect, you can continue channeling it and release it during PHASE in the next round. You can't release an ability if you are SILENCED .

## Phase 7: Full Attack

## Full Attack

## PHASE FULL ATTACK

1/round , choose one of the following:

- Ø You use a Slow ability.
- Ø You perform any two of the following actions VOLLEY , FIGHT , SHOVE , or GRAPPLE . You can choose the same action twice, but not the same ability or the same linked pair of weapons.

## Phase 8: Delay

## Delay

## PHASE DELAY

The last chance to take an action during this round. If you wanted to take an action but the phase had already passed, you can do so in this phase.

## REACTIONS

## Counterattack REACTION (1/ROUND), FOCUS 1

Trigger: You are hit by an attack from a character within the REACH of one of your abilities.

Effect: You can VOLLEY or FIGHT against that character with one of those abilities. Each attack roll can only be counterattacked once - multiple characters can't COUNTERATTACK in response to the same attack roll.

## Interpose REACTION, FOCUS 1

## Any Phase

## Ready

## ANY PHASE

You prepare your standard action at a later moment, turning it into a customizable reaction:

1.  Select a trigger, which must be a specific action , movement , or reaction taken by any character.
2.  Select your effect, which must be an action or minor action you can take during your current turn.
3.  Until the start of your next turn, you can perform that readied action as a reaction when the trigger is met. If you haven't used your readied action by the start of your next turn, the action is lost. You can't use any other reactions while you have an action readied. You can forgo yur readied action at any time.

## Example:

Trigger: Any enemy moves outside of cover. Effect: I will VOLLEY at them.

## Opportunity Attack REACTION (1/ROUND)

Trigger: An ally within RANGE 3 is targeted by an attack.

Effect: You can shift up to 2 spaces. If you end this movement next to the targeted ally, you can choose to become the target instead, even if you would otherwise not be a valid target. Each attack roll can only be interposed once - multiple characters can't INTERPOSE in response to the same attack roll.

Trigger: An enemy begins a movement within the REACH of one of your abilities.

Effect: You can immediately VOLLEY or FIGHT against that character with one of those abilities.
